declarations.name: Args
declarations.doc_comment:
CLI arguments container.
Positional arguments stored in `_`, named flags/options as string keys.
Used after initial CLI parsing (mri, minimist, etc.) for schema validation.

declarations.name: ArgValue
declarations.doc_comment: Value types supported in CLI arguments.

declarations.name: ArgSchema
declarations.doc_comment:
Schema description for help text generation.
Not used by args_parse/args_serialize directly - provided for consumers
building CLI help output.

declarations.name: ArgsAliasesResult
declarations.doc_comment:
Result of alias extraction from a schema.
Includes canonical keys for downstream conflict detection.

declarations.name: args_validate_schema
declarations.doc_comment:
Validates a zod schema for CLI arg usage.

Checks for:
- Alias conflicts with canonical keys
- Duplicate aliases across different keys

Results are cached per schema (WeakMap). Safe to call multiple times.
declarations.type_signature: (schema: ZodType<unknown, unknown, $ZodTypeInternals<unknown, unknown>>): { success: true; } | { success: false; error: ZodError<unknown>; }
declarations.return_type: { success: true; } | { success: false; error: ZodError<unknown>; }
declarations.return_description: Validation result with success flag and optional error

parameters.name: schema
parameters.description: Zod object schema with optional alias metadata

declarations.name: args_parse
declarations.doc_comment:
Validates parsed CLI args against a zod schema.

Handles CLI-specific concerns before validation:
1. Validates schema (cached) - returns error if alias conflicts exist
2. Expands aliases defined in schema `.meta({aliases: ['v']})`
3. Strips alias keys (required for strictObject schemas)
4. Validates with zod
5. After validation, syncs `no-` prefixed boolean flags with their base keys

Schema analysis is cached per schema (WeakMap) for performance.
declarations.type_signature: <TOutput extends Record<string, ArgValue> = Args>(unparsed_args: Args, schema: ZodType<TOutput, unknown, $ZodTypeInternals<TOutput, unknown>>): ZodSafeParseResult<...>
declarations.return_description: Zod SafeParseResult with expanded/synced data on success

parameters.name: unparsed_args
parameters.description: Args object from CLI parser (mri, minimist, etc.)

parameters.name: schema
parameters.description: Zod object schema with optional alias metadata

declarations.name: args_serialize
declarations.doc_comment:
Serializes Args to CLI string array for subprocess forwarding.

Handles CLI conventions:
- Positionals first, then flags
- Single-char keys get single dash, multi-char get double dash
- Boolean `true` becomes bare flag, `false` is skipped
- `undefined` values are skipped
- `no-` prefixed keys skipped when base key is truthy (avoid contradiction)
- When schema provided, extracts aliases and prefers shortest form

Schema analysis is cached per schema (WeakMap) for performance.
declarations.type_signature: (args: Args, schema?: ZodType<unknown, unknown, $ZodTypeInternals<unknown, unknown>> | undefined): string[]
declarations.return_description: Array of CLI argument strings

parameters.name: schema
parameters.description: Optional zod schema to extract aliases for short form preference

declarations.name: args_extract_aliases
declarations.doc_comment:
Extracts alias mappings and canonical keys from a zod schema's metadata.

Useful for consumers building custom tooling (help generators, conflict detection, etc.).
Results are cached per schema (WeakMap).
declarations.return_description: Object with aliases map and canonical_keys set

parameters.name: schema
parameters.description: Zod object schema with optional `.meta({aliases})` on fields

declarations.name: each_concurrent
declarations.doc_comment:
Runs an async function on each item with controlled concurrency.
Like `map_concurrent` but doesn't collect results (more efficient for side effects).
examples:
```ts
await each_concurrent(
  file_paths,
  async (path) => { await unlink(path); },
  5, // max 5 concurrent deletions
);
```
declarations.type_signature: <T>(items: T[], fn: (item: T, index: number) => Promise<void>, concurrency: number): Promise<void>

parameters.name: fn
parameters.description: async function to apply to each item

declarations.name: map_concurrent
declarations.doc_comment: Maps over items with controlled concurrency, preserving input order.
declarations.type_signature: <T, R>(items: T[], fn: (item: T, index: number) => Promise<R>, concurrency: number): Promise<R[]>
declarations.return_description: promise resolving to array of results in same order as input

parameters.name: fn
parameters.description: async function to apply to each item

declarations.name: map_concurrent_settled
declarations.doc_comment:
Like `map_concurrent` but collects all results/errors instead of failing fast.
Returns an array of settlement objects matching the `Promise.allSettled` pattern.
declarations.type_signature: <T, R>(items: T[], fn: (item: T, index: number) => Promise<R>, concurrency: number): Promise<PromiseSettledResult<R>[]>
declarations.return_description: promise resolving to array of `PromiseSettledResult` objects in input order

parameters.name: fn
parameters.description: async function to apply to each item

declarations.name: BenchmarkStats

Complete statistical analysis of timing measurements.
Includes outlier detection, descriptive statistics, and performance metrics.
All timing values are in nanoseconds.

modules.module_comment:
Benchmark-specific statistical analysis.
Uses the general stats utilities from stats.ts for timing/performance analysis.
All timing values are in nanoseconds.

declarations.name: BenchmarkConfig
declarations.doc_comment: Configuration options for a benchmark suite.

properties.name: duration_ms
properties.doc_comment:
Target duration to run each benchmark task in milliseconds.
The benchmark will run until this duration is reached or max_iterations is hit.
Default: 1000ms

properties.name: warmup_iterations
properties.doc_comment:
Number of warmup iterations before actual measurements.
Warmup helps stabilize JIT compilation and caches.
Default: 5

properties.name: cooldown_ms
properties.doc_comment:
Cooldown time between tasks in milliseconds.
Helps prevent interference between benchmarks.
Default: 100ms

properties.name: min_iterations
properties.doc_comment:
Minimum number of iterations to run.
Default: 10

properties.name: max_iterations
properties.doc_comment:
Maximum number of iterations to run.
Prevents infinite loops if function is extremely fast.
Default: 100000

properties.name: timer
properties.doc_comment:
Custom timer to use for measurements.
Default: timer_default (auto-detects environment)

properties.name: on_iteration
properties.type_signature: (task_name: string, iteration: number, abort: () => void) => void
properties.doc_comment:
Callback invoked after each iteration completes.
Useful for triggering garbage collection, logging progress, early termination,
or custom instrumentation.

**Note**: The callback time is NOT included in iteration measurements - it runs
after the timing capture. However, frequent GC calls will slow overall benchmark
execution time.

properties.name: on_task_complete
properties.type_signature: (result: BenchmarkResult, index: number, total: number) => void
properties.doc_comment:
Callback invoked after each task completes.
Useful for logging progress during long benchmark runs.

Useful for temporarily disabling tasks during development.

properties.name: only

properties.name: async

Hint for whether the function is sync or async.
If not provided, automatically detected during warmup.
Setting this explicitly skips per-iteration promise checking for sync functions.

declarations.name: deep_equal
declarations.doc_comment:
Deep equality comparison that checks both structure and type.

Key behaviors:

- Compares by constructor to prevent type confusion (security: `{}` â‰  `[]`, `{}` â‰  `new Map()`, `new ClassA()` â‰  `new ClassB()`)
- Prevents asymmetry bugs: `deep_equal(a, b)` always equals `deep_equal(b, a)`
- Compares only enumerable own properties (ignores prototypes, symbols, non-enumerable)
- Special handling for: Date (timestamp), Number/Boolean (boxed primitives), Error (message/name)
- Promises always return false (cannot be meaningfully compared)
- Maps/Sets compare by reference for object keys/values
declarations.return_description: true if deeply equal, false otherwise

declarations.name: is_editable
declarations.doc_comment:
Checks if the given element is editable.
Returns `true` for text-based input types, textareas, and contenteditable elements.

declarations.name: inside_editable
declarations.doc_comment: Returns `true` if the element is within a `contenteditable` ancestor.

declarations.name: is_interactive
declarations.doc_comment:
Checks if the element is interactive (clickable, focusable, or otherwise accepts user input).
Returns `true` for buttons, links, form controls,
and elements with interactive attributes and ARIA roles.

declarations.name: fetch_value
declarations.doc_comment:
Specializes `fetch` with some slightly different behavior and additional features:

- throws on ratelimit errors to mitigate unintentional abuse
- optional `parse` function called on the return value
- optional cache (different from the browser cache,
	 the caller can serialize it so e.g. dev setups can avoid hitting the network)
- optional simplified API for authorization and data types
  (you can still provide headers directly)

Unlike `fetch`, this throws on ratelimits (status code 429)
to halt whatever is happpening in its tracks to avoid accidental abuse,
but returns a `Result` in all other cases.
Handling ratelimit headers with more sophistication gets tricky because behavior
differs across services.
(e.g. Mastodon returns an ISO string for `x-ratelimit-reset`,
but GitHub returns `Date.now()/1000`,
and other services may do whatever, or even use a different header)

It's also stateless to avoid the complexity and bugs,
so we don't try to track `x-ratelimit-remaining` per domain.

If the `value` is cached, only the cached safe subset of the `headers` are returned.
(currently just `etag` and `last-modified`)
Otherwise the full `res.headers` are included.

declarations.doc_comment: Git workspace status flags indicating which types of changes are present.

declarations.name: git_parse_workspace_status
declarations.doc_comment:
Parses the output of `git status --porcelain -z` (v1 format) into a status object.
This is a pure function that can be tested independently.

Format: XY path\0 where:
- X = staged status (index)
- Y = unstaged status (work tree)
- path = file path (unescaped with -z)

Supported status codes:
- M = modified
- A = added
- D = deleted
- R = renamed
- C = copied
- T = type changed (regular file, symbolic link or submodule)
- U = unmerged
- ? = untracked
- ! = ignored

For renames/copies: XY new\0old\0 (two NUL-separated paths)

Note: This implementation treats submodules the same as regular files.
Submodule-specific status codes (lowercase m, ?) are interpreted as changes.
declarations.return_description: status object with flags for unstaged changes, staged changes, and untracked files

declarations.name: git_check_workspace
declarations.doc_comment:
Checks the git workspace status using a single `git status --porcelain -z` call.
The -z format provides more reliable parsing by using NUL separators and avoiding escaping.
declarations.return_description: status object with flags for unstaged changes, staged changes, and untracked files

- `'error'`: Only errors
- `'warn'`: Errors and warnings
- `'info'`: Errors, warnings, and info (default)
- `'debug'`: All messages including debug

declarations.name: Logger
declarations.doc_comment:
Simple, flexible logger with support for child loggers and automatic context.

Features:
- Instance-based configuration (no global state)
- Child loggers with automatic label concatenation
- Parent chain inheritance for level, console, and colors
- Respects NO_COLOR environment variable

members.name: constructor
members.doc_comment: Creates a new Logger instance.

parameters.name: label
parameters.description:
Optional label for this logger. Can be `undefined` for no label, or an
empty string `''` which is functionally equivalent (both produce no brackets in output).
Note: Empty strings are only allowed for root loggers - child loggers cannot have empty labels.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: Optional configuration for level, colors, and console

members.name: clear_level_override
members.doc_comment:
Clears the level override for this logger, restoring inheritance from parent.
After calling this, the logger will dynamically inherit the level from its parent
(or use the default level if it has no parent).

members.name: clear_colors_override
members.doc_comment:
Clears the colors override for this logger, restoring inheritance from parent.
After calling this, the logger will dynamically inherit colors from its parent
(or use the default colors behavior if it has no parent).

members.name: clear_console_override
members.doc_comment:
Clears the console override for this logger, restoring inheritance from parent.
After calling this, the logger will dynamically inherit the console from its parent
(or use the global console if it has no parent).

members.name: child
members.doc_comment:
Creates a child logger with automatic label concatenation.
Children inherit parent configuration unless overridden.
members.return_description: New Logger instance with concatenated label

parameters.name: label
parameters.description:
Child label (will be concatenated with parent label using `:`).
Cannot be an empty string - empty labels would result in confusing output like `parent:`
with a trailing colon. Use `undefined` or `''` only for root loggers.

throws.description: if label is an empty string

members.name: error
members.doc_comment:
Logs an error message with `ðŸž©errorðŸž©` prefix.
Only outputs if current level is `error` or higher.

members.name: warn
members.doc_comment:
Logs a warning message with `âš‘warnâš‘` prefix.
Only outputs if current level is `warn` or higher.

members.name: info
members.doc_comment:
Logs an informational message.
Unlike error/warn/debug, info has no character prefix - only the label is shown.
This keeps standard output clean since info is the default log level.
Only outputs if current level is `info` or higher.

members.name: debug
members.doc_comment:
Logs a debug message with `â”†debugâ”†` prefix.
Only outputs if current level is `debug`.

members.name: raw
members.doc_comment:
Logs raw output without any prefix, formatting, or level filtering.
Bypasses the logger's level checking, prefix formatting, and color application entirely.
Useful for outputting structured data or when you need full control over formatting.

Note: This method ignores the configured log level - it always outputs regardless of
whether the logger is set to 'off' or any other level.

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Values to log directly to console

properties.name: level
properties.doc_comment:
Log level for this logger instance.
Inherits from parent or defaults to 'info'.

properties.name: console
properties.doc_comment:
Console interface for output.
Inherits from parent or defaults to global console.
Useful for testing.

properties.name: colors
properties.doc_comment:
Whether to use colors in output.
Inherits from parent or defaults to enabled (unless NO_COLOR env var is set).

declarations.name: SpawnResultError

examples: ENOENT when command not found

declarations.name: SpawnResultExited
declarations.doc_comment:
Process ran and exited with a code.
`ok` is true when `code` is 0.

declarations.name: SpawnResultSignaled
declarations.doc_comment: Process was terminated by a signal (e.g., SIGTERM, SIGKILL).

declarations.name: SpawnResult
declarations.doc_comment:
Discriminated union representing all possible spawn outcomes.
Use type guards `spawn_result_is_error`, `spawn_result_is_signaled`,
and `spawn_result_is_exited` to narrow the type.

declarations.name: spawn_result_is_error
declarations.doc_comment: Type guard for spawn errors (process failed to start).

declarations.name: spawn_result_is_signaled
declarations.doc_comment: Type guard for signal termination.

declarations.name: spawn_result_is_exited
declarations.doc_comment: Type guard for normal exit with code.

declarations.name: SpawnProcessOptions
declarations.doc_comment: Options for spawning processes, extending Node's `SpawnOptions`.

properties.name: signal
properties.doc_comment:
AbortSignal to cancel the process.
When aborted, sends SIGTERM to the child.

properties.name: timeout_ms
properties.doc_comment:
Timeout in milliseconds. Must be non-negative.
Sends SIGTERM when exceeded. A value of 0 triggers immediate SIGTERM.

declarations.name: DespawnOptions
declarations.doc_comment: Options for killing processes.

properties.name: signal
properties.doc_comment: Signal to send.

properties.name: timeout_ms
properties.doc_comment:
Timeout in ms before escalating to SIGKILL. Must be non-negative.
Useful for processes that may ignore SIGTERM. A value of 0 triggers immediate SIGKILL escalation.

declarations.name: SpawnedProcess
declarations.doc_comment: Handle for a spawned process with access to the child and completion promise.

properties.name: child
properties.doc_comment: The underlying Node.js ChildProcess

properties.name: closed
properties.doc_comment: Resolves when the process exits

declarations.name: SpawnedOut

properties.name: stderr

declarations.name: ProcessRegistry
declarations.doc_comment:
Manages a collection of spawned processes for lifecycle tracking and cleanup.

The default instance `process_registry_default` is used by module-level functions.
Create separate instances for isolated process groups or testing.

members.name: processes
members.doc_comment: All currently tracked child processes

members.name: spawn
members.doc_comment:
Spawns a process and tracks it in this registry.
The process is automatically unregistered when it exits.
members.type_signature: (command: string, args?: readonly string[], options?: SpawnProcessOptions | undefined): SpawnedProcess

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: - Arguments to pass to the command

members.name: spawn_out
members.doc_comment:
Spawns a process and captures stdout/stderr as strings.
Sets `stdio: 'pipe'` automatically.
members.type_signature: (command: string, args?: readonly string[], options?: SpawnProcessOptions | undefined): Promise<SpawnedOut>
members.return_description:
Result with captured `stdout` and `stderr`.
- `null` means spawn failed (ENOENT, etc.) or stream was unavailable
- `''` (empty string) means process ran but produced no output
- non-empty string contains the captured output

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: - Arguments to pass to the command

members.name: despawn
members.doc_comment: Kills a child process and waits for it to exit.
members.return_description: The spawn result after the process exits

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: - Kill options including signal and timeout

members.name: despawn_all
members.doc_comment: Kills all processes in this registry.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: - Kill options applied to all processes

members.name: attach_error_handler
members.doc_comment:
Attaches an `uncaughtException` handler that kills all processes before exiting.
Prevents zombie processes when the parent crashes.

By default uses SIGKILL for immediate termination. Set `graceful_timeout_ms`
to attempt SIGTERM first (allowing processes to clean up) before escalating
to SIGKILL after the timeout.

Note: Node's uncaughtException handler cannot await async operations, so
graceful shutdown uses a blocking busy-wait. This may not be sufficient
for processes that need significant cleanup time.
members.type_signature: (options?: { to_error_label?: ((err: Error, origin: UncaughtExceptionOrigin) => string | null) | undefined; map_error_text?: ((err: Error, origin: UncaughtExceptionOrigin) => string | null) | undefined; handle_error?: ((err: Error, origin: UncaughtExceptionOrigin) => void) | undefined; graceful_timeout_ms?: number | ... 1 more ... | undefined; } | undefined): () => void
members.return_description: Cleanup function to remove the handler

parameters.name: options
parameters.type: { to_error_label?: ((err: Error, origin: UncaughtExceptionOrigin) => string | null) | undefined; map_error_text?: ((err: Error, origin: UncaughtExceptionOrigin) => string | null) | undefined; handle_error?: ((err: Error, origin: UncaughtExceptionOrigin) => void) | undefined; graceful_timeout_ms?: number | ... 1 more...

declarations.name: process_registry_default
declarations.doc_comment:
Default process registry used by module-level spawn functions.
For testing or isolated process groups, create a new `ProcessRegistry` instance.

declarations.name: spawn_process
declarations.doc_comment:
Spawns a process with graceful shutdown behavior.
Returns a handle with access to the `child` process and `closed` promise.
declarations.type_signature: (command: string, args?: readonly string[], options?: SpawnProcessOptions | undefined): SpawnedProcess

declarations.name: spawn
declarations.doc_comment:
Spawns a process and returns a promise that resolves when it exits.
Use this for commands that complete (not long-running processes).
declarations.type_signature: (command: string, args?: readonly string[], options?: SpawnProcessOptions | undefined): Promise<SpawnResult>

declarations.name: spawn_out
declarations.doc_comment: Spawns a process and captures stdout/stderr as strings.
declarations.type_signature: (command: string, args?: readonly string[], options?: SpawnProcessOptions | undefined): Promise<SpawnedOut>

declarations.name: despawn
declarations.doc_comment: Kills a child process and returns the result.

declarations.name: despawn_all
declarations.doc_comment: Kills all processes in the default registry.

declarations.doc_comment: Attaches an `uncaughtException` handler to the default registry.

declarations.doc_comment: Formats a child process for display.
examples: `pid(1234) <- node server.js`

declarations.name: print_spawn_result
declarations.doc_comment:
Formats a spawn result for display.
Returns `'ok'` for success, or the error/signal/code for failures.

declarations.name: spawn_result_to_message
declarations.doc_comment: Formats a spawn result for use in error messages.

declarations.name: RestartableProcess
declarations.doc_comment:
Handle for a process that can be restarted.
Exposes `closed` promise for observing exits and implementing restart policies.

properties.name: restart
properties.doc_comment:
Restart the process, killing the current one if active.
Concurrent calls are coalesced - multiple calls before the first completes
will share the same restart operation.

properties.name: kill
properties.doc_comment: Kill the process and set `active` to false

properties.name: active
properties.doc_comment:
Whether this handle is managing a process.

Note: This reflects handle state, not whether the underlying OS process is executing.
Remains `true` after a process exits naturally until `kill()` or `restart()` is called.
To check if the process actually exited, await `closed`.

properties.name: child
properties.doc_comment: The current child process, or null if not active

properties.name: closed
properties.doc_comment: Promise that resolves when the current process exits

properties.name: spawned
properties.doc_comment:
Promise that resolves when the initial `spawn_process()` call completes.

Note: This resolves when the spawn syscall returns, NOT when the process
is "ready" or has produced output. For commands that fail immediately
(e.g., ENOENT), `spawned` still resolves - check `closed` for errors.

declarations.name: spawn_restartable_process
declarations.doc_comment:
Spawns a process that can be restarted.
Handles concurrent restart calls gracefully.

Note: The `signal` and `timeout_ms` options are reapplied on each restart.
If the AbortSignal is already aborted when `restart()` is called, the new
process will be killed immediately.
declarations.type_signature: (command: string, args?: readonly string[], options?: SpawnProcessOptions | undefined): RestartableProcess

declarations.name: process_is_pid_running
declarations.doc_comment:
Checks if a process with the given PID is running.
Uses signal 0 which checks existence without sending a signal.
declarations.return_description:
`true` if the process exists (even without permission to signal it),
`false` if the process doesn't exist or if pid is invalid (non-positive, non-integer, NaN, Infinity)

parameters.name: pid
parameters.description: - The process ID to check (must be a positive integer)

declarations.name: create_random_alea
declarations.doc_comment:
Seeded pseudo-random number generator.
DO NOT USE when security matters, use webcrypto APIs instead.

declarations.name: random_float

declarations.type_signature: (min: number, max: number, random?: () => number): number

declarations.name: random_int
declarations.doc_comment:
Returns a random integer between `min` and `max` inclusive.
Node's `randomInt` is similar but exclusive of the max value, and makes `min` optional -
https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v20.x/api/crypto.html#cryptorandomintmin-max-callback
declarations.type_signature: (min: number, max: number, random?: () => number): number

declarations.name: random_boolean

declarations.type_signature: <T extends ReadonlyArray<any>>(arr: T, random?: () => number): ArrayElement<T>

declarations.doc_comment: Mutates `array` with random ordering.

parameters.name: random
parameters.type: ((min: number, max: number, random?: () => number) => number) | undefined

declarations.name: escape_regexp
declarations.doc_comment: Escapes a string for literal matching in a RegExp.

declarations.name: reset_regexp
declarations.doc_comment:
Reset a RegExp's lastIndex to 0 for global and sticky patterns.
Ensures consistent behavior by clearing state that affects subsequent matches.

declarations.name: Result
declarations.doc_comment:
An alternative pattern to throwing and catching errors.
Uses the type system to strongly type error return values when desired.
Catching errors is then reserved for unexpected situations.

declarations.name: OK
declarations.doc_comment: Frozen object representing a successful result.

declarations.name: NOT_OK
declarations.doc_comment: Frozen object representing a failed result.

declarations.name: unwrap
declarations.doc_comment:
A helper that says,
"hey I know this is wrapped in a `Result`, but I expect it to be `ok`,
so if it's not, I understand it will throw an error that wraps the result".
declarations.type_signature: <TValue extends { value?: unknown; }, TError extends { message?: string; }>(result: Result<TValue, TError>, message?: string | undefined): TValue["value"]
declarations.return_description: The wrapped value.

declarations.name: ResultError
declarations.doc_comment:
A custom error class that's thrown by `unwrap`.
Wraps a failed `Result` with an optional message,
and also accepts an optional message that overrides the result's.
Useful for generic handling of unwrapped results
to forward custom messages and other failed result data.

members.name: constructor
members.type_signature: (result: { ok: false; message?: string | undefined; }, message?: string | undefined, options?: ErrorOptions | undefined): ResultError

declarations.name: unwrap_error
declarations.doc_comment:
A helper that does the opposite of `unwrap`, throwing if the `Result` is ok.
Note that while `unwrap` returns the wrapped `value`, `unwrap_error` returns the entire result.
declarations.type_signature: <TError extends object>(result: Result<object, TError>, message?: string): { ok: false; } & TError
declarations.return_description: The type-narrowed result.

declarations.name: DeclarationKind
declarations.doc_comment: The kind of exported declaration.
declarations.type_signature: ZodEnum<{ function: "function"; type: "type"; variable: "variable"; class: "class"; constructor: "constructor"; component: "component"; json: "json"; css: "css"; }>

declarations.name: GenericParamInfo
declarations.doc_comment: Generic type parameter information.
declarations.type_signature: ZodObject<{ name: ZodString; constraint: ZodOptional<ZodString>; default_type: ZodOptional<ZodString>; }, $loose>

declarations.name: ParameterInfo
declarations.doc_comment:
Parameter information for functions and methods.

Kept distinct from ComponentPropInfo despite structural similarity.
Function parameters form a tuple with positional semantics:
calling order matters (`fn(a, b)` vs `fn(b, a)`),
may include rest parameters and destructuring patterns.
declarations.type_signature: ZodObject<{ name: ZodString; type: ZodString; optional: ZodOptional<ZodBoolean>; description: ZodOptional<ZodString>; default_value: ZodOptional<...>; }, $loose>

declarations.name: ComponentPropInfo
declarations.doc_comment:
Component prop information for Svelte components.

Kept distinct from ParameterInfo despite structural similarity.
Component props are named attributes with different semantics:
no positional order when passing (`<Foo {a} {b} />` = `<Foo {b} {a} />`),
support two-way binding via `$bindable` rune.
declarations.type_signature: ZodObject<{ name: ZodString; type: ZodString; optional: ZodOptional<ZodBoolean>; description: ZodOptional<ZodString>; default_value: ZodOptional<...>; bindable: ZodOptional<...>; }, $loose>

declarations.name: DeclarationJson
declarations.doc_comment:
Metadata for an exported declaration (function, type, class, component, etc.).

Extracted from TypeScript source and JSDoc/TSDoc comments at build time.
declarations.type_signature: ZodObject<{ name: ZodString; kind: ZodEnum<{ function: "function"; type: "type"; variable: "variable"; class: "class"; constructor: "constructor"; component: "component"; json: "json"; css: "css"; }>; ... 19 more ...; alias_of: ZodOptional<...>; }, $loose>

modules.module_comment:
Metadata types for library source code analysis.

These types represent the structure of `src/lib/` exports,
extracted at build time via TypeScript compiler analysis.
Used for generating API documentation and enabling code search.

Hierarchy: SourceJson â†’ ModuleJson â†’ DeclarationJson

declarations.name: stats_mean
declarations.doc_comment: Calculate the mean (average) of an array of numbers.

declarations.name: stats_median
declarations.doc_comment: Calculate the median of an array of numbers.

declarations.name: stats_std_dev
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculate the standard deviation of an array of numbers.
Uses population standard deviation (divides by n, not n-1).
For benchmarks with many samples, this is typically appropriate.

declarations.name: stats_variance
declarations.doc_comment: Calculate the variance of an array of numbers.

declarations.name: stats_percentile
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculate a percentile of an array of numbers using linear interpolation.
Uses the "R-7" method (default in R, NumPy, Excel) which interpolates between
data points for more accurate percentile estimates, especially with smaller samples.

declarations.name: stats_cv
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculate the coefficient of variation (CV).
CV = standard deviation / mean, expressed as a ratio.
Useful for comparing relative variability between datasets.

declarations.name: stats_min_max
declarations.doc_comment: Calculate min and max values.

declarations.name: StatsOutlierResult
declarations.doc_comment: Result from outlier detection.

properties.name: cleaned
properties.doc_comment: Values after removing outliers

properties.name: outliers
properties.doc_comment: Detected outlier values

declarations.name: StatsOutliersIqrOptions
declarations.doc_comment: Configuration options for IQR outlier detection.

properties.name: iqr_multiplier
properties.doc_comment: Multiplier for IQR bounds (default: 1.5)

properties.name: min_sample_size
properties.doc_comment: Minimum sample size to perform outlier detection (default: 3)

declarations.name: stats_outliers_iqr
declarations.doc_comment:
Detect outliers using the IQR (Interquartile Range) method.
Values outside [Q1 - multiplier*IQR, Q3 + multiplier*IQR] are considered outliers.

declarations.name: StatsOutliersMadOptions
declarations.doc_comment: Configuration options for MAD outlier detection.

properties.name: z_score_threshold
properties.doc_comment: Modified Z-score threshold for outlier detection (default: 3.5)

properties.name: z_score_extreme
properties.doc_comment: Extreme Z-score threshold when too many outliers detected (default: 5.0)

properties.name: mad_constant
properties.doc_comment: MAD constant for normal distribution (default: 0.6745)

properties.name: outlier_ratio_high
properties.doc_comment: Ratio threshold to switch to extreme mode (default: 0.3)

properties.name: outlier_ratio_extreme
properties.doc_comment: Ratio threshold to switch to keep-closest mode (default: 0.4)

properties.name: outlier_keep_ratio
properties.doc_comment: Ratio of values to keep in keep-closest mode (default: 0.8)

properties.name: min_sample_size
properties.doc_comment: Minimum sample size to perform outlier detection (default: 3)

properties.name: iqr_options
properties.doc_comment: Options to pass to IQR fallback when MAD is zero

declarations.name: stats_outliers_mad
declarations.doc_comment:
Detect outliers using the MAD (Median Absolute Deviation) method.
More robust than IQR for skewed distributions.
Uses modified Z-score: |0.6745 * (x - median) / MAD|
Values with modified Z-score > threshold are considered outliers.

declarations.name: STATS_CONFIDENCE_Z_SCORES
declarations.doc_comment: Common z-scores for confidence intervals.

declarations.name: stats_confidence_level_to_z_score
declarations.doc_comment:
Convert a confidence level (0-1) to a z-score.
Uses a lookup table for common values, approximates others.
examples:
```ts
stats_confidence_level_to_z_score(0.95); // 1.96
stats_confidence_level_to_z_score(0.99); // 2.576
```

declarations.name: StatsConfidenceIntervalOptions
declarations.doc_comment: Configuration options for confidence interval calculation.

properties.name: z_score
properties.doc_comment: Z-score for confidence level (default: 1.96 for 95% CI)

properties.name: confidence_level
properties.doc_comment: Confidence level (0-1), alternative to z_score. If both provided, z_score takes precedence.

declarations.name: stats_confidence_interval
declarations.doc_comment: Calculate confidence interval for the mean.
declarations.return_description: [lower_bound, upper_bound]

declarations.name: stats_confidence_interval_from_summary
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculate confidence interval from summary statistics (mean, std_dev, sample_size).
Useful when raw data is not available.
declarations.type_signature: (mean: number, std_dev: number, sample_size: number, options?: StatsConfidenceIntervalOptions | undefined): [number, number]
declarations.return_description: [lower_bound, upper_bound]

declarations.name: StatsWelchTTestResult
declarations.doc_comment: Result from Welch's t-test calculation.

properties.name: t_statistic
properties.doc_comment: The t-statistic

properties.name: degrees_of_freedom
properties.doc_comment: Welch-Satterthwaite degrees of freedom

declarations.name: stats_welch_t_test
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculate Welch's t-test statistic and degrees of freedom.
Welch's t-test is more robust than Student's t-test when variances are unequal.
declarations.type_signature: (mean1: number, std1: number, n1: number, mean2: number, std2: number, n2: number): StatsWelchTTestResult

declarations.name: stats_normal_cdf
declarations.doc_comment: Standard normal CDF approximation (Abramowitz and Stegun formula 7.1.26).

declarations.name: stats_ln_gamma
declarations.doc_comment: Log gamma function approximation (Lanczos approximation).

declarations.name: stats_incomplete_beta
declarations.doc_comment:
Approximate regularized incomplete beta function for p-value calculation.
Uses continued fraction expansion for reasonable accuracy.
declarations.type_signature: (x: number, a: number, b: number): number

declarations.name: stats_t_distribution_p_value
declarations.doc_comment:
Approximate two-tailed p-value from t-distribution.
For large df (>100), uses normal approximation.
For smaller df, uses incomplete beta function.
declarations.return_description: Two-tailed p-value

modules.module_comment:
Statistical analysis utilities.
Pure functions with zero dependencies - can be used standalone for any data analysis.

declarations.name: truncate
declarations.doc_comment: Truncates a string to a maximum length, adding a suffix if needed that defaults to `...`.
declarations.type_signature: (str: string, maxLength: number, suffix?: string): string

declarations.name: strip_start
declarations.doc_comment: Removes characters inclusive of `stripped`.

declarations.name: strip_end
declarations.doc_comment: Removes characters inclusive of `stripped`.

declarations.name: strip_after
declarations.doc_comment: Removes characters inclusive of `stripped`.

declarations.name: strip_before
declarations.doc_comment: Removes characters inclusive of `stripped`.

declarations.name: ensure_start
declarations.doc_comment: Adds the substring `ensured` to the start of the `source` string if it's not already present.

declarations.name: ensure_end
declarations.doc_comment: Adds the substring `ensured` to the end of the `source` string if it's not already present.

declarations.name: deindent
declarations.doc_comment: Removes leading and trailing spaces from each line of a string.

declarations.name: plural
declarations.doc_comment: Returns a plural suffix based on a count.
declarations.type_signature: (count: number | null | undefined, suffix?: string): string

declarations.name: count_graphemes
declarations.doc_comment: Returns the count of graphemes in a string, the individually rendered characters.

declarations.name: strip_ansi
declarations.doc_comment: Strips ANSI escape sequences from a string

declarations.name: stringify
declarations.doc_comment: Stringifies a value like `JSON.stringify` but with some corner cases handled better.

declarations.name: string_display_width
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculate the display width of a string in terminal columns.
- Strips ANSI escape codes (they have 0 width)
- Emojis and other wide characters take 2 columns
- Tab characters take 4 columns
- Newlines and other control characters take 0 columns
- Uses `Intl.Segmenter` to properly handle grapheme clusters (e.g., family emoji "ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘§â€ðŸ‘¦")

declarations.name: pad_width
declarations.doc_comment: Pad a string to a target display width (accounting for wide characters).

declarations.name: levenshtein_distance
declarations.doc_comment:
Calculates the Levenshtein distance between two strings.
Useful for typo detection and fuzzy matching.
declarations.return_description: The edit distance between the strings

properties.name: delay
properties.doc_comment: Enforced milliseconds between calls. For `when='trailing'` this is the debounce delay.

properties.name: when
properties.doc_comment: When to call the throttled function. Defaults to `both`.

declarations.name: throttle
declarations.doc_comment:
Throttles calls to a callback that returns a void promise.
Immediately invokes the callback on the first call unless `leading=false`.
If the throttled function is called while the promise is already pending,
the call is queued to run after the pending promise completes plus `delay`,
and only the last call is invoked.
In other words, all calls and their args are discarded
during the pending window except for the most recent.
Unlike debouncing, this calls the throttled callback
both on the leading and trailing edges of the delay window by default,
and this can be customized by setting `leading` or `trailing.
It also differs from a queue where every call to the throttled callback eventually runs.
declarations.type_signature: <T extends (...args: Array<any>) => Promise<void>>(cb: T, { delay, when }?: ThrottleOptions): T
declarations.return_description: same as `cb`

declarations.name: Timer
declarations.doc_comment:
Timer interface for measuring elapsed time.
Returns time in nanoseconds for maximum precision.

properties.name: now
properties.doc_comment: Get current time in nanoseconds

declarations.name: timer_node
declarations.doc_comment:
Node.js high-resolution timer using process.hrtime.bigint().
Provides true nanosecond precision.

declarations.name: timer_browser
declarations.doc_comment:
Browser high-resolution timer using performance.now().
Converts milliseconds to nanoseconds for consistent API.

**Precision varies by browser due to Spectre/Meltdown mitigations:**
- Chrome: ~100Î¼s (coarsened)
- Firefox: ~1ms (rounded)
- Safari: ~100Î¼s
- Node.js: ~1Î¼s

For nanosecond-precision benchmarks, use Node.js with `timer_node`.

declarations.name: timer_default
declarations.doc_comment:
Auto-detected timer based on environment.
Uses process.hrtime in Node.js, performance.now() in browsers.
The timer function is detected once and cached for performance.

declarations.name: TIME_NS_PER_US
declarations.doc_comment: Time units and conversions.

declarations.name: time_ns_to_us
declarations.doc_comment: Convert nanoseconds to microseconds.

declarations.name: time_ns_to_ms
declarations.doc_comment: Convert nanoseconds to milliseconds.

declarations.name: time_ns_to_sec
declarations.doc_comment: Convert nanoseconds to seconds.

declarations.name: TimeUnit
declarations.doc_comment: Time unit for formatting.

declarations.name: TIME_UNIT_DISPLAY
declarations.doc_comment: Display labels for time units (uses proper Unicode Î¼ for microseconds).

declarations.name: time_unit_detect_best
declarations.doc_comment:
Detect the best time unit for a set of nanosecond values.
Chooses the unit where most values fall in the range 1-9999.
declarations.return_description: Best unit to use for all values

declarations.name: time_format
declarations.doc_comment: Format time with a specific unit.
declarations.type_signature: (ns: number, unit: TimeUnit, decimals?: number): string
declarations.return_description: Formatted string like "3.87Î¼s"

declarations.name: time_format_adaptive
declarations.doc_comment: Format time with adaptive units (ns/Î¼s/ms/s) based on magnitude.
examples:
```ts
time_format_adaptive(1500) // "1.50Î¼s"
time_format_adaptive(3870) // "3.87Î¼s"
time_format_adaptive(1500000) // "1.50ms"
time_format_adaptive(1500000000) // "1.50s"
```
declarations.return_description: Formatted string like "3.87Î¼s" or "1.23ms"

declarations.name: TimeResult
declarations.doc_comment:
Result from timing a function execution.
All times in nanoseconds for maximum precision.

properties.name: elapsed_ns
properties.doc_comment: Elapsed time in nanoseconds

properties.name: elapsed_us
properties.doc_comment: Elapsed time in microseconds (convenience)

properties.name: elapsed_ms
properties.doc_comment: Elapsed time in milliseconds (convenience)

properties.name: started_at_ns
properties.doc_comment: Start time in nanoseconds (from timer.now())

properties.name: ended_at_ns
properties.doc_comment: End time in nanoseconds (from timer.now())

declarations.name: time_async
declarations.doc_comment: Time an asynchronous function execution.
declarations.type_signature: <T>(fn: () => Promise<T>, timer?: Timer): Promise<{ result: T; timing: TimeResult; }>
declarations.return_description: Object containing the function result and timing information

declarations.name: time_sync
declarations.doc_comment: Time a synchronous function execution.
declarations.type_signature: <T>(fn: () => T, timer?: Timer): { result: T; timing: TimeResult; }
declarations.return_description: Object containing the function result and timing information

declarations.name: time_measure
declarations.doc_comment: Measure multiple executions of a function and return all timings.
declarations.type_signature: (fn: () => unknown, iterations: number, timer?: Timer): Promise<number[]>
declarations.return_description: Array of elapsed times in nanoseconds

modules.module_comment:
Time utilities.
Provides cross-platform high-resolution timing and measurement helpers.

declarations.name: create_stopwatch
declarations.doc_comment: Tracks elapsed time in milliseconds.

declarations.name: Timings
declarations.doc_comment:
Tracks and manages multiple timing operations.
Allows starting, stopping, and retrieving timings with optional precision.

members.name: start
members.doc_comment: Starts a timing operation for the given key.

members.name: merge
members.doc_comment:
Merges other timings into this one,
adding together values with identical keys.

declarations.name: PickUnion
declarations.doc_comment: Like `Pick` but works for type unions.

declarations.name: KeyofUnion
declarations.doc_comment: Like `keyof` but works for type unions.

declarations.name: Flavored
declarations.doc_comment:
The `Flavored` and `Branded` type helpers add varying degrees of nominal typing to other types.
This is especially useful with primitives like strings and numbers.
see_also: https://spin.atomicobject.com/typescript-flexible-nominal-typing/ * `Flavored` is a looser form of `Branded` that trades explicitness and a little safety in some cases for ergonomics. With `Flavored` you don't need to cast unflavored types: * ```ts type Email = Flavored<string, 'Email'>; const email1: Email = 'foo'; // ok type Address = Flavored<string, 'Address'>; const email2: Email = 'foo' as Address; // error! ``` * `Branded` requires casting: * ```ts type PhoneNumber = Branded<string, 'PhoneNumber'>; const phone1: PhoneNumber = 'foo'; // error! const phone2: PhoneNumber = 'foo' as PhoneNumber; // ok ``` * See also Zod's `.brand` schema helper:

declarations.name: format_url
declarations.doc_comment:
Formats a URL by removing 'https://', 'www.', and trailing slashes.
Notably it does not remove 'http://', so the user can see that it's insecure.
